DOCNAME: CASE OF KOBENTER AND STANDARD VERLAGS GMBH v. AUSTRIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 10;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - domestic proceedings;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant , an NORP national born in DATE and living in GPE , is an editorial journalist at the newspaper “ FAC ” . The second applicant is the owner and publisher of this newspaper .

CARDINAL . On DATE a group of homosexuals , the “ NORP Forum of NORP and NORP ” ( “ GPE Schwulen- PERSON ” , ORG ) held a demonstration in GPE Pölten , at which the editors of the magazine “ Der CARDINAL . – Zeitung der Katholiken für GPE und Kirche ” ( DATE Newspaper of NORP for ORG ) took pictures of participants and published them together with an article written by PERSON in its issue of CARDINAL DATE . That article reflected a negative and hostile position towards homosexual relationships , suggesting , inter alia , that “ they [ homosexuals ] ought to be disciplined ' gender - specifically ' with whips and pizzles ! ( sie gehören ' geschlechtsspezifisch ' PERSON und ORG zurechtgewiesen ) ” and that “ nazi - methods should be applied to them ! ” It read further that “ homosexuals now crawl like rats out of their holes and are fed ' lovingly ' by politicians and church officials ” .

CARDINAL . Subsequently CARDINAL homosexual persons filed a private prosecution ( PERSON ) against the author PERSON for defamation and a compensation claim under LAW against the owner and publisher of “ LAW . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) found that certain passages of the article constituted the offence of insult ( PERSON ) under LAW of LAW ) and ordered the owner and publisher of “ Der CARDINAL . ” to pay compensation to CARDINAL plaintiffs who could be identified on the pictures . It dismissed the compensation claim as regards the other plaintiffs and acquitted PERSON The court found that PERSON NORP had not mentioned any of those plaintiffs ' name in his article and that it could not be established that he had known that his text would be illustrated by these pictures . On pages CARDINAL the judgment contained an excursus about the nature of homosexuality , referring to a book called “ Lexicon of love ( PERSON der PERSON ) ” and the results of an opinion survey on this topic . It read , inter alia , that “ in truth , homosexuality includes also the lesbian world and , of course , that of animals ” , which was followed by a long passage describing in detail examples of same - sex practices among different animals .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , politicians and representatives of ORG publicly criticised the deciding judge PERSON for the text and style of this judgment , which was documented in a number of press releases by ORG ( ORG ) of CARDINAL DATE , CARDINAL and DATE , including an article published by “ Der Standard ” with the title “ The judge and the dear cattle ( Der Richter und das liebe Vieh ) ” on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE “ Der Standard ” published CARDINAL articles written by the first applicant , whereby the first one referred to the commentary ( ORG ) at issue on page CARDINAL , which read as follows :
“ The punishment chamber ( PERSON )
PERSON

It is strange how often the avowed defenders of western values are inclined to adopt draconian methods when they feel them to be jeopardised by people with different beliefs , ideas or lifestyles . If a writer in some odd rag just says he would like to flog gay people or beat them with bulls ' pizzles , that would not normally be worth mentioning , other than to say that everyone is entitled to live out his sexual fantasies and obsessions as he pleases , even in words , as long as the objects or subjects of his desires derive as much pleasure from it as he does .

Where such matters are being dealt with in court , however , we might expect at DATE that a judge of even minimal enlightenment would , at the very least , deliver a judgment that differs more than somewhat from the traditions of medieval witch trials . A judge in GPE , PERSON , has achieved the feat of acquitting a defendant who was given the benefit of the doubt although no doubt was apparent – on the contrary , the judge 's reasoning handed the flogger enough arguments to justify the threats of punishment he had made so enthusiastically , even if only in writing . That flies in the face , for a start , of any conception of law which sees the courtroom as more than just a punishment chamber for all possible tendencies .

Lending support to a homophobe 's venomous hate campaign with outrageous examples from the animal kingdom casts doubt on the intellectual and moral integrity of the judge concerned . The fact that public clarifications are now needed to the effect that homosexuals are not animals prompts concern about the state of this country . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE judge PERSON decided that the above - mentioned excursus on pages CARDINAL be taken out of the judgment of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . NORP Subsequently disciplinary proceedings were opened against judge PERSON B. On DATE ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) , acting as disciplinary authority , imposed the disciplinary penalty of a warning . On DATE ORG ( Oberster Gerichtshof ) confirmed this decision .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , judge PERSON filed a private prosecution against the first applicant for defamation ( Üble Nachrede ) and a compensation claim under LAW against the second applicant on account of the above article published on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG convicted the first applicant of defamation under LAW CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW and imposed a fine of ORG CARDINAL ( EUR CARDINAL ) on him , suspended on DATE . It also ordered the second applicant to pay ORG CARDINAL ( EUR CARDINAL ) in compensation to judge PERSON under LAW of LAW and to publish the judgment . It found in particular that the following statements were capable of lowering judge PERSON in the public esteem , constituting the slanderous reproach that he had violated his obligations under the law and the rules on professional conduct ( Gesetzes- und Standespflichten ) , required of a judge :

a ) the judgment delivered by the private prosecutor would only differ somewhat from the traditions of medieval witch trials ( das vom Privatankläger gefällte ORG würde sich nur “ marginal PERSON mittelalterlicher ORG abheben ” ) and

b ) that judge PERSON would lend support to a homophobe 's venomous hate campaign with outrageous examples from the animal kingdom ( und dieser würde “ die geifernde Hetze eines LOC DATE aus dem Tierreich stützen ” ) .

CARDINAL . The ORG noted , inter alia , that even if the reasoning of that judgment contained irrelevant annotations , it could not be inferred from it that the private prosecutor PERSON believed that different rights were accorded to homosexuals and heterosexuals , nor that he had compared homosexuals with animals or that he had put them on an equal footing .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants appealed against this judgment , claiming that the article at issue criticised exclusively the reasoning of the judgment and not the way in which judge PERSON had conducted the trial . The statements were permissible value judgments based on facts and , thus , protected under LAW . Arguing that journalistic liberty also allowed a certain degree of exaggeration and even provocation , and considering the public discussion caused by the reasoning of the judgment not only in various media but also among judges , the polemical style of the article was not disproportionate either .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicants ' appeal and confirmed ORG judgment . It found that an average reader , interested in the subject - matter , would understand by the first statement that the private prosecutor had grossly violated fundamental procedural rights , such as the principles of impartiality and adversarial hearings , which were regularly breached in medieval witch trials . Thus , this reproach of violating the rules on professional conduct required of a judge consisted in concrete facts , which were not proved true by the records of the trial . The second statement was not only a value judgment , but also insinuated that judge PERSON had sided with the accused PERSON and had , thus , been partial . As it was not mentioned in the article that judge PERSON had impartially conducted the trial and that only certain passages of the judgment were subject to that criticism , the statements could not be considered as value judgments based on facts . Rather , in their context , they were disparaging statements of facts , falling outside the scope of protection of LAW . Since certain passages of the above judgment proved to be legally superfluous , as affirmed by the private prosecutor 's decision of DATE taking them out , they could have been subject to ( fair ) comment .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW provides for the strict liability of the publisher in cases of defamation ; the victim can thus claim damages from him . In this context “ defamation ” has been defined in LAW ) , as follows :

“ CARDINAL . As it may be perceived by a third party , anyone who makes an accusation against another of having a contemptible character or attitude , or of behaving contrary to honour or morality , and of such a nature as to make him contemptible or otherwise lower him in public esteem , shall be liable to imprisonment not exceeding DATE or a fine ( ... )

CARDINAL . Anyone who commits this offence in a printed document , by broadcasting or otherwise , in such a way as to make the defamation accessible to a broad section of the public , shall be liable to imprisonment not exceeding one year or a fine ( ... )

CARDINAL . The person making the statement shall not be punished if it is proved to be true . As regards the offence defined in paragraph CARDINAL , he shall also not be liable if circumstances are established which gave him sufficient reason to assume that the statement was true . "
